ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Yes, with the caveat that classmates' backgrounds are incredibly diverse and that it's difficult to 'speak the same language'.

AMST 702 is a great introduction to mobility studies with a feminist take on the matter. I would recommend the course to you if you want theadvantage of wielding the mobility lens in your research--you come to understand soon enough that mobility permeates almost every aspect of our lives.

I would say that American Studies 702 provides an introduction to a field of American Studies, mobility paradigms. This paradigm is incredibly multifaceted and encompasses a mutltitude of theoretical frameworks. The class is organized so that two students co-present the weeks readings together, focusing on key questions for the classroom discussion. We write a weekly response and a weekly response following the class. At the end of the semester, we are expected to write a small research paper. The writing encompasses a total of less than 40 pages, which is manageable. I highly recommend taking classes with Professor Grewal, which cares deeply about her students and is very wiling to offer additional guidance through the class and also through grad school.

I would summarize the course as a really fun and exciting theoretical introduction to mobility paradigm in interdisciplinary studies. Coming from a more theoretical and cultural studies background I really enjoyed the theoretical, intersectional, and interdisciplinary analyses aspects of the course. I would definitely recommend it to a student that is interested in looking at cultural theory and mobility in a number of contexts.

Yes, I would highly recommend the course. I think this is a good introduction into a wide variety of disciplines. All of the readings were engaging and because the course is cross-listed, it attracts a diverse group of students which makes for stimulating discussions.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: This class engaged me in a growing part of the field of American Studies. Beginning my classes, I believe it is critical to know the intellectual debates currently within American Studies, to better understand my own position within the field. I believe this overview of the mobility paradigms achieved this goal. The class also allowed me the space to begin to write about JINSA, which I had been previously unaware of. A detailed analysis of this organization's operations may prove to be part of my dissertation.

I think this course helped me explore my research interests and how I want to approach research questions and topics. It help me take intellect risks and explore areas of study I didn't know existed. In that way, I think it helped me deepen my knowledge of the discipline very much and helped me explore my intellectual identity. In those ways, the course helped me think about my dissertation/research in the sense that it helped me think about the kinds of areas I want to study and how I might contribute to different fields in the future.
I will be able to integrate some of the theory and readings into my dissertation research. It introduced me to a diverse field that I hope to remain engaged with as I continue my studies.
